The manual will serve as a permanent reference book for the process and will be the primary tool used for training all existing and future employees. Sulfur Dioxide (SO2) Smelting/Converting Furnace Off-Gas System



B. GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM

The centerpiece of the accidental release prevention program is the Risk Management Program (RMP).  The fourteen (14) elements of the RMP constitute the framework by which process safety and accident prevention are managed in the unit.  These fourteen (14) individual elements of our prevention program work together to prevent accidental chemical releases. KUC and our employees are committed to the standards required by these management systems and to the prevention of accidental releases.  In addition to the above prevention program elements, we also have specific prevention measures that are employed as part of our operating procedures and engineering and administrative controls to help contain/control a release, quickly detect a release, and reduce the consequences of a release.  These measures are briefly summarized as follows:

General Risk Reduction and Safety Measures:

? Engineering and construction in accordance with recognized Industry and company standards

? Equipment properly designed with protection from overpressure

? Updated technical drawings, piping & instrument diagrams and process flow diagrams

? Operating systems monitored and controlled 24 hrs. a day by trained operators

? Computerized monitoring and control of process operations

? Automatic and manual shutdown devices for critical systems

? Scheduled inspection, testing, and preventive maintenance of process equipment

? Limited facility access and 24 hr. security force

? Radio communication system

? Closed circuit television surveillance capabilities

? Frequent unit surveillance by operators

? Automatic and remotely operated shut-offs to limit release quantity

? Strategically located valves and dampers to isolate leaks

? Toxic gas detectors at key areas to warn of a sulfur dioxide release



General Emergency Response:

? An Emergency Response Team specializing in fire control, spill control, rescue, HAZMAT and emergency medical treatment with monthly training provided.

? Emergency Response Technicians on duty 24 hours per day

? Emergency Management System to manage and coordinate response to emergencies

? Emergency response apparatus specially designed for industrial fire protection

? Site wide emergency alert system

? Annual emergency response training for all employees

? Communication with local emergency responders and regulatory agencies

? Periodic emergency response drills with plant personnel, regulatory agencies, and community emergency responders to enhance response skills and coordination among agencies

? Mutual Aid with the Salt Lake County Unified Fire Authority 

? Participation with the Salt Lake County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC)

Executive Summary



The Rio Tinto Kennecott Smelter is designed, operated, and maintained in a manner that protects the environment, as well as the health and safety of our employees, contractors, and the community in which we operate.  We promote health, safety, and the environment through programs of awareness, compliance, prevention and protection.  These programs include a combination of accidental release prevention programs and emergency response planning programs.  This document provides a brief overview of the comprehensive risk management activities that we have designed and implemented, including:



A.    Description of our facility and the use of substances regulated by EPA's Risk Management Plan (RMP) rule.

B.    Overview of our accidental release prevention programs.

C.    Five-year accident history for accidental releases.

D.    Overview of our emergency response program.

E.    Overview of planned changes to improve safety.



This accidental release prevention program is being submitted to establish an RMP for the Furnace Off-Gas System as well the inclusion of the existing Process Safety Management Plan for the Off-Gas Conversion section of the Acid Plant.



A. STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES

The Rio Tinto Kennecott Smelter, Furnace Off-Gas system is located approximately 5 miles west of Magna, Utah.   The Smelter receives concentrated ore (concentrate) produced from the nearby Bingham Canyon Mine and processes it through a set of high-temperature furnaces to produce a high-grade copper anode. The combustion of the sulfur-bearing copper concentrate in the furnaces generates an exhaust stream of which sulfur dioxide (SO2) is a significant component. This exhaust stream is then captured by the Off-Gas system and transported via ductwork to the Sulfuric Acid Production area, where the SO2 is converted into Sulfur Trioxide (SO3) with Sulfuric acid (H2SO4) being the final product offered for sale to various industrial markets.

se the following chemicals that EPA has identified as having the potential to cause significant offsite consequences in the event of a major accidental release:



Toxics

The amount of Sulfur Dioxide in the Furnace Off-Gas system exceeds the threshold quantity in the RMP regulation.  The Rio Tinto Kennecott Smelter is located a safe distance from any residential area, however, it is located adjacent to an independent industrial facility providing production materials for the Smelting process. It is the proximity of this facility (public receptor) and the additional presence of a chemical covered by the OSHA PSM regulation, Sulfur Trioxide (although not it is below EPA Threshold  quantity), that mandate the Rio Tinto Kennecott Smelter be classified as "Prevention Program Level 3" as set forth in Section 68 of the EPA regulations.



Flammables

The Kennecott Utah Copper Smelter does not use, store, or handle any flammable materials covered by the RMP regulation. The Smelter does store propane for use strictly as fuel gas for the operation of our own furnaces in the event our natural gas supply is curtailed or interrupted, however, the EPA considers fuel gas stored for this purpose to be exempt from the RMP rule.

The Emergency Response Plan and its implementation follow the National Incident Management System (NIMS) Incident Command System.

The facility also maintains its own dedicated emergency response equipment.  This equipment includes portable fire extinguishers, self-contained breathing apparatus (SCBA), encapsulated chemical protective suits, rescue and medical equipment, and firefighting apparatus capable of delivering high volumes of water and firefighting foam.  An inspection, testing and preventive maintenance program is in place for emergency response equipment.



E. PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Rio Tinto Kennecott is continually striving to make the Smelter a safe workplace for our employees, contractors, our neighbors and our community.  Our focus is safe, reliable, and environmentally sound operations, and proactive management of these issues.  Process Hazard Assessments (PHA) have recently been performed for the furnace Off-Gas system, as well as the Sulfuric Acid Production unit. These assessments are designed to identify opportunities for improvement. Compliance audits of the RMP program are conducted every three years, and any changes found in the PHA are required to be resolved within one year. These recommendations are presently being resolved as will any future opportunities for the prevention of accidental release per the regulatory schedule referenced above.

D. EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The Facility maintains compliance with local, state, and federal regulations including OSHA CFR 1910.120 Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response, and SARA Title III.  Our emergency response program is reviewed and updated on an annual basis, or more often if required.  Our program provides the essential planning and training for protecting employees, the public, and the environment during emergency situations.  The program includes written procedures that outline the actions to be taken for various types of emergencies that could occur in the facility. These emergencies include: airborne releases of hazardous chemicals, spills to the water or ground, fires, explosions, personnel rescue incidents and medical emergencies. The programs address all aspects of emergency response including:



? Information on the plant emergency organization (Incident Command System)

? Information on the roles and responsibilities of personnel responding to the incident

? Procedures for notifying employees that a release has occurred

? Procedures for plant evacuation and accounting of personnel

? Procedures to notify local emergency response organizations and other appropriate authorities that a release has occurred

? Guidance on proper first aid and medical treatment for chemical exposures

? Procedures for post incident cleanup and decontamination



An important part of the plant emergency organization is the Emergency Response Team (ERT). The ERT is made up of full-time emergency response employees, as well as employee volunteers.
